title: Journal Pre-proofs Review Unplanned absorption of sunscreen ingredients: impact of formulation and evaluation methods

body_text.text: The skin is the most exposed human organ, and in vitro and in vivo studies on skin cells had already shown that ultraviolet (UV) radiation can damage its molecules and structures (Balogh et al., 2011; González et al., 2008; Marrot and Meunier, 2008) . When UV radiation reaches the skin, one part is reflected, and another part is absorbed into its various layers (Gallagher and Lee, 2006; Grant and Heisler, 2006) .

Wavelengths in the UVB region (~320 nm) are mainly absorbed by epidermal cells components, such as proteins or DNA, while UVA radiation (320-400 nm) penetrates deep into the skin, reaching the basal layer of the epidermis and even dermal fibroblasts (Gallagher and Lee, 2006) . UVA particularly affects connective tissue, increasing the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Balogh et al., 2011; Gallagher and Lee, 2006; Grant and Heisler, 2006; Trojahn et al., 2015) . The excessive amount of ROS promotes oxidation reaction in the cells, which may cause DNA damage ultimately leading to genetic mutation, and possible melanoma formation and actinic keratosis development (Trojahn et al., 2015) .

According to World Health Organization (Who, 2003) , UV radiation exposition, especially during childhood and adolescence, is related the rise numbers of skin cancer cases, being its main etiological agent. In tropical countries, such as Brazil, skin cancer appears as the prevalent cancer type. From 2020-2022, according to National Cancer Institute (INCA), the prediction is 83,770 new skin cancer cases in man and 93,160 in women per year (Inca, 2019).

Despite cancer, ROS may also induce photo aging, which plays an important role in wrinkles formation. Oxidation reaction stimulates fibroblasts to increase production of metalloproteinase complex which inhibits the collagen production, causing loss of skin thickness and elasticity, resulting in progressive skin atrophy and laxity (Balin and Pratt, 1989; Bucay and Day, 2013; Pilkington et al., 2015; Roh and Chung, 2009) .

To reduce the damage caused by ROS, sunscreens are used to protect skin against UVA/B. Although, to guarantee the effectiveness and present better protection against UVA/B, sunscreens must remain on the surface of the epidermis (Durand et al., 2009; Montenegro et al., 2011) .

However, permeation of sun filter components through the skin may occur influencing not only its performance and safety but also offering risk to users when it reaches systemic circulation (Montenegro et al., 2008) . One of the harmful effects of some sunscreen agents is to induce apoptosis (Butt and Christensen, 2000) . When in systemic circulation, it can cause increase of estrogen effect, leading to rapidly cancer cells growth, as shown by a uterotrophic effect caused by sunscreen agent (Heneweer et al., 2005b; Schlumpf et al., 2001 ). Heneweer et al. (2005a) studied the potential of the following UV filters, 3-(4methylbenzylidene) camphor (4-MBC), octyl methoxy cinnamate (OMC), 2,4-dihydroxybenzophenone (BP-1) and 2-Hydroxy-4-methoxybenzophenone (BP-3) when absorbed, to stimulate the estrogen receptor. Authors found that UV filter not only stimulates the receptor, but increases the production of estrogen in long term use.

Even if sunscreens meet regulatory agencies requirements, low molecular weight and inorganic filters could enhance skin permeation, leading to further dermis absorption and adverse reactions (Gilbert et al., 2013; Skotarczak et al., 2015) .

Potential toxicity of chemical filters when applied to the skin, may occur by sensibilization of viable cutaneous strata and through transdermal route, for this reason skin permeation studies are important for the development of a safe and effective sunscreen (Touitou and Godin, 2008) .
To assure that, in vitro and in vivo methods were developed to detect skin absorption.

Furthermore, it is important to stablish the difference between the terms of percutaneous absorption (transdermal absorption) and penetration (absorption). Penetration occurs when a topical product, applied on the skin surface, causes local effect from passive diffusion into the skin. Transdermal absorption is related to medication applied on the skin with the purpose of penetration through skin layers to reach systemic circulation (Suhonen et al., 1999; Wilbur, 2017) .

The absorption through the skin is related to the presence of some components used as pharmaceutic agents to incorporate a formulation and carry the UV filter, although, these components can work indirectly as promoters/enhancers in sunscreen's formulation. Surfactants agents, as isopropyl palmitate, olive oil and others, interact with cell membrane and improve skin permeability. The same occurs in the presence of phospholipids (Barry, 1991; Williams, 2004) .
The aim of this review is to approach skin absorption of sunscreens components, revisiting the use of in vitro and in vivo methods to determinate possible skin absorption.

Data collection was done through Web of Science, Pubmed, Virtual library of heath (BVS) and Wiley Online Library covering a period of 2010 to 2020. The terms used in the data search were "sunscreen", "sunscreen agent", "formulation", "skin absorption", "in vitro", "in vivo", "permeation studies", "transwell", "franz cell", "dialyze bag", "flow-through", "microdialysis", "tape stripping", "raman", "spray", "vehicle", "stick", "gel", "lotion" and "towellets". Moreover, not included were scientific articles addressing unfocused in sunscreen skin absorption, method of detection and formulations.

Sunscreen agents acts inhibiting the penetration of UV lights, by causing its dispersion (Palm and O'donoghue, 2007) . Inorganic UV filters reflect light and are mainly represented by titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) and zinc oxide (ZnO). Physical filters are considered safe and effective, with low potential for irritation, being even used in formulations for children and sensitive skin (Shaath, 2010) . Chemical UV filters absorb harmful UV rays, before transmitting it to the skin, and convert them into low-energy radiation, which is considered relatively safe. The most known and used filter are benzophenone-3 (BP-3), octyl methoxycinnamate (OMC), butyl methoxydibenzoylmethane (BMDBM), Avobenzone (AVO) and Octocrylene (OCT) (Cefali et al., 2016b ).

Studies between 2010 and 2020 reveled intense work in finding natural substitutions to synthetic sunscreens, given environmental problems that they may cause, which will be further discussed, and also other allergenic problems that may be caused by them.

Flavonoids and tannins are natural molecules containing UV-protection activities well known in the literature. Guava fruit extract contains higher amount of those molecules and its extract is able to absorb UVB (315nm-280nm) and UVA (400nm-315nm) radiation. When compared to 2-ethyl-hexyl methoxycinnamate (EHM), an FDA approved sunscreen, guava extract absorbance was lower, although the combination of EHM with the extract showed synergic interaction by increasing SPF of final formulation. Therefore, guava fruit extract may be an option to complement existent sunscreen formulation, and partially reduce the amount of synthetic sunscreen agents, reducing the final toxicity and the cost of the product (Mota et al., 2019) .

Raspberry and blueberry were known for their antioxidant activity due to anthocyanins presence. Extracts of both fruits were obtained and incorporated in a topical formulation, aiming the development of a final product with solar protection factor and antioxidant activity (Cefali et al., 2019e) . Peels of Benitaka grape were also used with the same aim (Cefali et al., 2019d) .

Rosmarinic acid is a molecule found in the plant P. amboinicus, which extract reveled high absorbance peak in UVB region (at 209 nm) and UVA region (at 330 nm), indicating large spectrum of action. These results corroborate to determine a great absorption capacity of these extract leading to a protective effect against ultraviolet rays, characterizing it as a potential sunscreen. Furthermore, extract SPF was 12,63, which was in accordance with Anvisa recommendation. The extract also showed great antioxidant activity, which increases the action spectrum, being advantageous to skin care, since it reduces free radical, preventing skin aging (Terto et al., 2020) . Cefali et al. (2019b) produced a mix extract rich in flavonoid, containing Ginkgo biloba L., Dimorphandra mollis Beth, Ruta graveolens, and Vitis vinifera L., which showed promising results.

Mixed extract showed protection against UVB and UVA radiation, with critical wavelength around 327 nm, SPF of 6.9, and UVA/UVB rate of 0.8. Obtained extract was further incorporated in a thermodynamically stable emulsion (Cefali et al., 2019c) and final formulation showed SPF of 2.4

and critical wavelength of 387 nm. Also, final formulation was not skin irritant, and rutin, selected as marker, was found in stratum corneum and deeper epidermis. The same mixed extract was also incorporated in chitosan nanoparticles with around 76% of encapsulation efficiency, and them incorporated into an emulsion, with SPF of 2.3 and critical wavelength of 387 (Cefali et al., 2019a ).

Therefore, it is possible to conclude that different plant extracts can be combined into one mixed extract, which could be incorporated in topical formulations, or even nanoencapsulated, protecting extract from environmental conditions, and also present SPF and antioxidant activity.

S. cristaefolium, a microalgae, was explored by Prasedya et al. (2019) , proving that algae not just was able to absorbed UVA light in the 340 nm-400nm region, but also reduces skin damage cause by UV-A after few days of treatment when compared to non-treated group. In mice, the histological analysis revealed that the photoprotective action happened because there were not thickness on the epidermal layer, which was seen in control group that was not treated. Thus, algae were able to keep skin integrity. Furthermore, the protection of algae was similar to the sunscreen product used as comparison in the study (SPF=30). The authors had reasons to believe that the molecule responsible for the photoprotective action was Microsporin-like Amino Acids (MAAs), specifically MAAs-palythene, commonly found in the microalgae and cyanobacterium.

Microsporin-like Amino Acids (MAAs) were conjugated with chitosan (CS-MAA), by Fernandes et al. (2015) . That combination increased UV-absorption capacity in both UVA and UVB radiations when compared to free MAA molecules. In addition, when compared to FDA approved sunscreen agents such as octyldimethyl p-aminobenzoic acid and ethylhexyl pmethoxycinnamate, the conjugate of CS-MAA were better effective in photoprotection (Fernandes et al., 2015) .

There are a variety of formulations on the market, because in addition to being safe and effective, they have to meet the specific needs of each segment of the population (Clares et al., 2011a; Cole, 2016a) . The choice of the best vehicle will depend on skin type , personal preferences and filter type (organic or inorganic) (Geoffrey et al., 2019; Yap et al., 2017) . The most common types of formulations are: emulsions, creams, gels, oils, sprays, mousses, powders, foundations, aerosols, sticks and towellets (Clares et al., 2011b; Geoffrey et al., 2019) . For example, for oily skin, gels and lotions are more indicated because they will not aggravate acne as much as creams.

Fatty formulations may be less comfortable to apply, as they tend to be thicker and thus result in less consumer acceptability and applicability. Sprays are quite commercialized, as they are easy to apply, but do not form an ideal coverage (Yap et al., 2017) .

Formulations can benefit from different delivery systems, such as polymeric nanoparticles, lipid nanoparticles, microcapsules, micro sponges and other (Bhuptani and Patravale, 2019; Cozzi et al., 2018; Gilbert et al., 2016; Marcato et al., 2011b; Martins et al., 2014) . Moreover, sunscreen can also be an ingredient in makeup and tanning products (Cole, 2016b) .

Emulsions are the best vehicles for sunscreens and have been the most sold protector in the world. The lotion formulation is more fluid containing higher amount of water, in the other hand creams are dense, and have more viscosity (Hewitt, 2016) . Cream sunscreens are the most purchased formulations with 49%, followed by lotions with 29% (Xu et al., 2016) . Even being a best seller, creams are generally more expensive than lotions. Emulsions can be easily applied to the face and the whole body, being a comfortable formulation to use (Gomez-Berrada et al., 2017) .

Emulsified systems (W/O or O/W) are composed of polar (water-soluble) and non-polar (fat-soluble) components, being able to carry water-soluble and water-insoluble filters (Hewitt, 2016) . O/W products are generally preferred by consumers, since water is the external phase and causes an immediate sensation of wetness on the skin. Moreover, when water evaporates it provides a refreshing feeling on the skin. This feeling of freshness can be improved with the addition of alcohol or other volatile substances in the formulation (Hewitt, 2016 ).

On the other hand, W/O emulsions are generally perceived as heavier. However, this occlusive feature is welcome in some cases, such as in winter sports and for babies, providing better protection (Hewitt, 2016) .

Moreover, facial foundations or pigmented sunscreen are a category of products that can complement facial sun protection. They are available in several presentations such as mousse, liquid, water-containing cream, soufflé, anhydrous cream, cake, stick, and shake lotion. Each type of formulation is composed of different ingredients and filters, so each has a different degree of facial protection (Draelos, 2016) .

The most commercialized facial foundation is liquid containing water, oils, titanium dioxide, and iron oxides. This type of formulation can be subdivided into water-based, oil-based, oil-free, and water-free forms. The water-based formulation is the most consumed base, as it is easy to apply, has quick drying, is non-occlusive and comes out with water, as it is an O/W emulsion. It may contain organic filters and inorganics (Draelos, 2016) .

Sunscreens in sprays are appealing to consumers since it can be easily and quickly applied (Teplitz et al., 2018) . A cross-sectional study carried out in the USA, between 2011 and 2016 observed an increase in sales of sunscreens in sprays from 35.1% to 38.0% (Xu et al., 2016) .

However, the spray is a less studied vehicle compared with others, and to ensure an effective application some factors need to be observed, such as distance from the skin and application angle, presence of wind and duration of spraying (Broussard et al., 2020; Teplitz et al., 2018) .

A disadvantage of the spray is the loss of approximately 25% of the content during application (Novick et al., 2015) . Furthermore, application coverage is below the minimum recommended of 2 mg/cm 2 , for sunscreens to be more effective. Finally, it is not recommended to apply spray close to the face or mouth to avoid inhalation, contributing for systemic absorption (Geoffrey et al., 2019; Perez et al., 2018) .

Gel is a semi-solid pharmaceutical presentation composed mostly of water, and a gelling agent, responsible for the firmness of the colloidal system (Budiman et al., 2019) . Gels are indicated for people with oily and acne skin once they are oil-free formulations (Abuçafy et al., 2016; Piquero-Casals et al., 2019; Yap et al., 2017) . This preparation has great spreadability besides offering comfort to the user during application (Budiman et al., 2019; Yati et al., 2019) . In addition, gels present excellent stability and controlled release compared to other semisolid formulations (Rina et al., 2019) . Deccache et al. (2010) observed that a sunscreen in gel form did not show significant variations in SPF at 25 °C or 40 °C for two weeks.

Gels are excipients obtained by synthetic (polymers and copolymers) or natural (gums and alginates) hydrophilic thickeners and are usually not able to protect at the same level as emulsions (Abuçafy et al., 2016; Flor et al., 2007) . Despite desirable, the development of transparent gels is challenging, since to do so sunscreens must be water-soluble and on the other side is necessary to use a mixture of filters that are mostly fat-soluble to obtain high protection levels (Flor et al., 2007) .

Another disadvantage of gel is the incorporation of inorganic filters, even in microparticles, because inorganic filters tend to aggregate, forming an inconvenient opaque aspect (Abuçafy et al., 2016; Flor et al., 2007) . That is why several studies with titanium dioxide nanoparticles are developed to improve their incorporation into gels (Abuçafy et al., 2016; Bahadur et al., 2010; Nesseem, 2011) .

Gel is an option for incorporating natural active. A study in Indonesia used a gel formulation to produce a sunscreen with mangiferin extracted from Phaleria macrocarpa fruits. Final formulation showed good spreadability and consistency, pH between 5.8 to 6.0, and no phase separation was observed. The SPF was 11.2, 38.6, and 88.53 depending on mangiferin concentration 1.25%, 2.5%, and 5%, respectively. The formulation remained stable during the 2 months of the stability study (Rina et al., 2019) .
Stick is a solid vehicle, not suitable for large body areas , being better for specific areas such as lip and sensitive parts of the face (Gomez-Berrada et al., 2017; Novick et al., 2015) .

A study analyzed the use of stick in patients with hyperpigmentation and found that this form of sunscreen may be the most suitable for mild to severe cases of hyperpigmentation, as it is easy to apply, has high water resistance and forms a cohesive and resistant protective film.

Formulations tested were tinted with iron oxides and FPS 70. In the first application, patients have reported an improvement in appearance, which may be due to the good coverage provided by the iron oxide pigments and the film provided by the stick formula combined with the high sun protection factor (Conceicao et al., 2019) .

Towellets are a pharmaceutical presentation used as a solid support impregnated with a sunscreen formulation. This presentation has numerous advantages such as good stability, safety, efficiency, easy applicability and is not sticky. In addition, it is easy to transport and preserve due to its single dose format. Towellets are a good option of sunscreen for children (Clares et al., 2011b) .

A study used towellets as vehicle to incorporate a sunscreen emulsion to improve skin sensory properties and to reduce problems found in market formulations as instability and ineffectiveness of formulation for pediatric use. Dry matter, pH, viscosity, density, and microbiological stability for sunscreen emulsion and impregnated towellets were evaluated, and towellets showed an adequate state of fluidity, being considered an interesting format for new sunscreen development (Clares et al., 2011b) .

A study in the United States analyzed attitudes, preferences, and behaviors among young adult males doing outdoor activities about sun protection. Participants used sunscreen in towellets form, lotion, wax stick, spray and clear gel and answered questions about ease of application, texture, packaging and scent. Towellets received the highest evaluations in all four categories and spray sunscreen had the second highest score. However, in a list of preferences according to the type, the spray came first. This may have happened because the men reported that they liked the towellets but they had never seen this shape and did not know how much to apply and if it really protected. For most men, the main criteria when selecting a sunscreen are the easiness and speed of uniform application, and familiarity with the product (Wickenheiser et al., 2013) .

Facial powder is generally used to cover imperfections, control skin oiliness, and provide a matte finish. However, it can also increase the durability of photoprotection if applied on top of the protector after drying. It also provides an extra layer of protection by increasing the SPF, as it contains organic filters in its composition (Draelos, 2016) .

Facial powders have in their composition pigments combined with talc, also known as hydrated magnesium silicate, which have the ability to camouflage the skin. Some other pigments include: titanium dioxide, magnesium carbonate, magnesium stearate, zinc stearate, prepared chalk, zinc oxide (Draelos, 2016) . Some of these pigments and minerals act as physical barrier for radiation (Serpone et al., 2007) . To be used alone, facial powder requires a higher concentration of titanium dioxide to obtain the needed SPF (Draelos, 2016) .

Facial powders can be opaque or transparent formulations. Opaque formulation attenuates the penetration of UV radiation in addition to preventing the transmission of visible light and can be applied over another product or alone. The opacity of the pigments should be around 25 μm since opacity is directly proportional to the powder's ability to protect from UV radiation. Transparent powders have a lower sun protection capacity, as they are more natural and allow light to reach the skin's surface. They should not be used alone as a protector but dusted over a sunscreen to increase protection. Its composition is similar to compact powder, but contains less talc, titanium dioxide, or zinc oxide (Draelos, 2016 ).

An Ag/Fe-enhanced TiO 2 nanoparticles powders by sol-gel method and microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis method was developed, and improved application of TiO 2 . The combination of Ag enhanced TiO 2 nanoparticles, showing higher absorbance of UV radiation, which leaded to an increasement of SPF value. In addition, this combination did not show any cytotoxicity, in fact, increase the proliferation of the amniotic fluid stem cells. Therefore, authors conclude that the use of the metallic combination, are effective to be used in sunscreen (Nicoara et al., 2020) .

Another study conducted by Teramura et al. (2018) , developed three types of powders foundation, in order to increase protection in cases of erythropoietic protoporphyria. Among formulations developed, the formulation containing ethylhexyl methoxycinnamate, benzophenone-3, titanium dioxide and iron oxide showed the highest porphyrin protection factors . However, sample containing ethylhexyl methoxycinnamate, titanium dioxide and iron oxide was the formulation with highest SPF and UVA protection. Authors conclude that powder foundations containing sunscreens may be an option to patients with erythropoietic protoporphyria conditions (Teramura et al., 2018) .

Sunscreen agents and formulation components permeation through the skin depends on its molecular characteristics such as polarity. Cell membranes are structured by lipids, which have affinity for lipophilic (apolar) molecules. The importance of these concepts is that the cell will offer different paths in which the sunscreen agent and formulation components will permeate into the stratum corneum and deeper layers (Lane, 2013) .
It is well known that skin, composed by epidermis and dermis, acts as a barrier, preventing entrance of microorganisms and other harmful substances and preventing water loss (Lane, 2013) .

Epidermis could be divided into stratum corneum, stratum lucidum, stratum granulosum, stratum spinosum and stratum basale (Yang et al., 2017) . Any component that permeates the skin, first has to cross the stratum corneum (10-20 m thick) the outermost layer of skin and the first of the epidermis. A dense layer, formed by highly keratinized dead cells, makes this the major barrier to transport. The intercellular space of the dead corneocytes are filled with lipids organized in lamellar bilayers.
In general, there are three main paths to components permeation through the skin ( Figure 1 ):
intercellular path (through the lipid bilayer), transcellular path (across the corneocytes) and

transappendageal path (through follicles and sweat glands) (Lane, 2013) . Depending on molecules characteristics, they will have a preferential path. For example, lipophilic compounds tend to permeate using intercellular path because of its lipid-rich nature; while very high weight, slowly diffusing and charged molecules may permeate through transappendageal path (Lane, 2013) .

For safety purposes and regulatory approval, permeation studies have to be done to assess the ability from some of the sunscreen agents to penetrate the skin and decide whether the formulation can be commercialized. Several methods can be employed to access permeability from a selected formulation. Studies using permeation methods applied to sunscreen agents, from the last 10 years, are described on Tables 1, 2 and 3. Those tables show that it is possible to access permeations using biological or synthetic barrier, varying methodology and the system used.

If no tissue is used to cover the gap between a donor chamber and a receptor chamber in a permeation test, but synthetic membrane is added, we can accept the membrane porous itself as the barrier to overcome (Yang et al., 2016) . Another possibility for in vitro test, is to cultivate cells on the membrane and use both as barriers (Yan et al., 2017) . When an extracted tissue is added as a barrier, it is called ex vivo test. The choice of the tissue type and its depth, comes from what the researcher is looking for on its experiment (Bacqueville and Mavon, 2008) . In vivo experiments require a set of animals to collect blood from. After topical application, this blood is tested to investigate if any compound permeated skin and reached blood stream (Gulson et al., 2012; Kim and Al., 2014; Vieira et al., 2019) .

Those different barriers can be use in different methodologies, using different systems to hold or grow the chosen barrier. Here we are going to describe some of the well-known systems used for permeations essays.

The system was developed by Bronaugh and Stewart (1985) and consists of multiple cells ( Figure 2 ) most used to determine the deposition effect of an active agent, caused by a formulation on the skin. The method uses similar conditions as Franz cell, as further described (Bronaugh and Stewart, 1985) . Although, the sample addition is smaller than Franz cell, given the size of donor chamber. In comparison with the static diffusion cells, the flow-through system creates even closer physiologic conditions, based on the continuous replacement of the receptor fluid (Vallet et al., 2007) .

In summary, flow-through system is an old method that has been substituted by Franz cells diffusion, a fact that is supported by the year of publications using this system. When searching for papers using this method, only four studies returned, and three of them were older than proposed study time in this review (Gupta et al., 1999; Kenney et al., 1995; Nakai et al., 1997) . Table 1 contain the studies that explores these methods in the period determined in the methodology.

One of the most used in vitro methods to evaluate the permeation of UV filters, is the diffusion cell or Franz cell (Franz, 1975) . The methodology is based on transport by diffusion (through a membrane), defined as the passage of a substance (from the donate chamber to the receptor chamber, Figure 3 ) following a concentration gradient, as explained by the Fick's first law (Bartosova and Bajgar, 2012) . The method includes determination of certain conditions, such as: membranes, temperature, receptor fluid, sink conditions and time of sample collection. These method advantages include minor handling of tissue, samples are collected in pre determinated times (automaticly in some cases) and a small amount of sample is necessary for analysis (Tables 2,   3 and 4) (Salamanca et al., 2018 ).

On the other hand, the Franz cell diffusion are more advantageous compared to flowthrough system, because of the equipment price, simpler design, and there are no technical features, excepting the magnetic stirrer, which reduces technical problems. Moreover, the Franz cell diffusion contour the ethical aspects (Bronaugh, 2004a, b; Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009) Dialyze bag

This method is based on osmose and diffusion laws ( Figure 4 ). In a becker or neutral recipient, the receptor solution is added, and inside the solution a floating cellulose bag containing the formulation. Similar to the methods above, this method requires sink condition. In every sample collection, the external fluid must be replaced with solution or the cellulose bag needs to be moved to a new becker with fresh solution (Table 5) (Sheehan, 2013) .

The method's advantages include applicability to higher sample volumes and possibility to change the composition of macromolecular solution. On the other hand, experiment lasts longer, since the equilibrium between inside and outside fluids takes a longer time to be reached. This fact may interfere into the loss of biological activity from the studied molecule (Sheehan, 2013) .

The tape stripping technique can be used in vivo and in vitro, to asses drug permeation (Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009; Lademann et al., 2017) . Overall, the formulation or substance in study is applied on a certain area of the skin or membrane ( layers (Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009) .

This technique inexpensive and non-invasive, since only dead cells are removed, furthermore it gives important information about the dermatopharmacokinetics of the substance passing through the stratum corneum layers (Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009; Lademann et al., 2017 ). However, the tape stripping method cannot be used as transdermal study since only removes the stratum corneum. Moreover, the method depends on the tape type, pressure applied, pulling straight and velocity and anatomical factors such as: age, gender, ethnical and local of application (Tables 3 and 6) (Bashir et al., 2001; Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009; Lademann et al., 2017; Löffler et al., 2004; Palenske and Morhenn, 1999) .

The method includes a closer clinical trial, which includes healthy volunteers without any skin disorders ( Figure 6 ). An area of the body is delimited and the formulation is applied. It needs to be in contact with the skin for a period of time or reapplied a few times. In the meantime, the volunteers are submitted to blood and urine collection, where the metabolites and the substance itself can be identify (Table 7) (Gulson et al., 2012; Kim and Al., 2014; Vieira et al., 2019) .

Raman, is a vibrational spectroscopy, which works by changing the molecules polarizability by vibrational transition in molecular vibration energy ( Figure 7 ) (Li and Church, 2014) . The energy transition occurs due to incidence of monochromatic light (photons) in a sample, and can be lost (Stokes) or gained (anti-Stokes) (Smith et al., 2016) . According to Mitsutake et al. (2019) Stokes phenomena has lower energy and longer wavelength, because of the transference of energy from photon to a molecule, and the anti-Stokes phenomena is the opposite of Stokes. In Zhu et al.
(2014) study it was described that Raman contains a lasers that excites the samples and could be He:Ne (632.8 nm), argon ion (458.0, 488.0 and 514.5 nm), krypton ion (530.9 and 647.1 nm),

He:Cd (441.6 nm), Nd:YAG (1,064 and 532 nm), and diode lasers (630 and 780 nm); monochromator that are responsible to disperse signal into its spectral components; detectors photomultiplier tubes (PMT) and charge-coupled device (CCD).

The technique is useful to detect the sunscreen permeation and is advantageous for been a simple form of detection, nondestructive, noninvasive and very fast for semi-quantitative analysis in vivo (Tippavajhala et al., 2018) . For pharmaceuticals applications the mains advantages of Raman are the absence of sample preparations, which means saving costs, the analysis can occur directly in the final package, the analysis results are quickly and the equipment requires minimally trained person for the experiments (Vankeirsbilck et al., 2002) . However, Raman spectroscopy obtention has high cost, the presence of impurities could mask or even making disappear the Raman signal due to their strong fluorescence, and the analyte may change their solid state and crystalline, or burn, because of the temperature that is used to excite the particles (Table 8) (Vankeirsbilck et al., 2002; Wang et al., 2018) .

Although the stratum corneum (SC) is considered to be an efficient barrier to external agents, several factors can influence skin permeation profile, including the UV filter and the formulation itself (Gilbert et al., 2016) . Even environmental factors such as pollution can cause skin overabsorption of sunscreens (Pan et al., 2015) . In this section, we will present some characteristics and strategies that can impact in sun filter permeation.
body_text.section: FORMULATION CHARACTERISTICS THAT IMPACTS IN SUNSCREEN PERMEATION

body_text.text: According with Chatelain et al. (2003) , vehicles properties can be related to different permeation rates, mainly when it is compared the permeation rate in the stratum corneum -more lipophilic; and dermis -more hydrophilic. It can be argued that, ingredients capable to increase the solubility of UV filters in the stratum corneum or improve the distribution in this skin layer can affect, not only safety, but also efficacy of these products, since for an oil-in-water (more hydrophilic) emulsion it was found the amount of filter retained in the stratum corneum was 3 times higher than a lipophilic vehicle and the respective SPF results was significant higher for the oil-inwater emulsion.

Regarding sunscreens formulation, it is suggested that emulsifying systems used for preparations of oil-in-water (O/W), water-in-oil (W/O), may affect sunscreen permeation, since the polar/non polar characteristics of emulsifiers or surfactants, can interact with stratum corneum by creating different pathways, mainly in the non polar area of stratum corneum , facilitating or even hindering the passage of these components through skin barrier (Klimová et al., 2015; Montenegro et al., 2011) .

In the work of Klimová et al. (2015) In addition, different galenic forms as oils, vaseline and emulsion may influence filters permeation in the skin Due to the amount of water present in the formulations and the polar/nonpolar matrix of the galenic form, there are difference of sunscreen permeation in the skin (Kim et al., 2014a ).
Furthermore, according to Montenegro and Puglisi (2013) (Idson, 1975 (Idson, , 1983 ).

On the other hand, many studies also connect higher rate of skin permeation to the use of specific galenic vehicles and even sun filters, as octyl salicylate. It has traditionally been used as a chemical sunscreen and is regarded as safe in concentrations up to 5% (v/v). In transdermal drug delivery, octyl salicylate has been used to enhance the permeation of testosterone and fentanyl through human skin in vitro using volatile formulations (Lane, 2013) .

There are limited data in the literature about the mechanism of permeation enhancement of octyl salicylate. Nevertheless, ATR-FTIR (Attenuated Total Reflectance Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy) studies conducted in vitro and in vivo suggested that it may reduce the conformational order of the lipid bilayers located within SC surface (Lane, 2013) .

Other results show that the formulation containing petrolatum may reduce the partition of chemicals between the stratum corneum and the emulsion, by causing occlusive effect (Roussel et al., 2015) . These findings show that the interaction of the vehicle components can also avoid the permeation of filters (Montenegro and Puglisi, 2013) .

Recently, many studies have shown the possibilities of sunscreen nanoencapsulation and its advantage such as permeation reduction by causing retention into the skin, hence effectiveness and photo stability (Cozzi et al., 2018; Siqueira et al., 2011) . Although, some studies contradict these advantages, considering that the use of nanocapsules showed permeation of some sunscreen agents, found in the biological samples, meaning that the sunscreen agent reached the circulation. With that in mind, it is safe to say that there is no consensus about the real retention of the nanocapsules by the skin.

As for ZnO, Gulson et al. (2012) used nanoencapsulation and figured that it did not hold the agent in skin surface, since ZnO was detected in urine and blood samples. However, the explanation for these finding includes a possibility of an acid catalyzation of the ZnO applied onto the skin. This catalyzation liberates zinc ions that permeate and cross over the stratum corneum, accessing the circulation which permit the detection in blood and urine (Holmes et al., 2016 ).

Nevertheless, Vieira et al. (2019) studied the nanoencapsulation of ZnO in Amorphous-15 which seemed to be a great method of nanoencapsulation to the agent, since shown increase of the SPF and toxicity reduction in vitro and in vivo.

Furthermore, TiO 2 nanoparticle, incorporated in sunscreens, were able to remain in the surface of stratum corneum, when compared to free TiO2, and independently of mechanical or solar radiation damage. The nanoparticle loaded with TiO2, when retained in the skin surface may reduce the toxic effect caused by the absorption of the TiO2 in the dermis, which can be seen in the free TiO2 formulation (Miquel-Jeanjean et al., 2012) .

Nanoencapsulation of the benzophenone-3 in chitosan-coated polymeric particles reduces potential skin absorption, retaining the active in skin surface for a longer time (Siqueira et al., 2011) . Similar results and benefits were obtained by Bhuptani and Patravale (2019) , who nanoencapsulated benzophenone-3 in starch micro sponges cream. Their results showed a significant decrease of skin absorption when compared to free benzophenone-3. In addition, the formulation was non-irritant and biocompatible (Bhuptani and Patravale, 2019) .

Moreover, in a study by Marcato et al. (2011a) , the comparison between benzophenone-3 free, encapsulated in poly(epsilon-caprolactone) nanoparticles and solid lipids nanocapsules, besides the results already established in the other studies (Cozzi et al., 2018; Gilbert et al., 2016; Martins et al., 2014; Weiss-Angeli et al., 2010) , suggested that the nanoparticle structure can impact on safety and efficacy, since both nano-structures performed better in the SPF increase and presented good carrier properties (Gilbert et al., 2016) .

Other methods, as the production of solid-lipid microparticles using natural bee wax, were successful when encapsulating benzophenone-3, also showing high photo stability and safety, in addition to SPF increase (Martins et al., 2014) .

As for the bio adhesives poly (D,L-lactic acid)-hyperbranched polyglycerol nanoparticles, the major advantage includes the possibility of combining more than one sunscreen agent, which increases skin protection. That technology may be more accessible, and may improve the quality of the products aesthetic. That is due to the amount of water in the formulation, replacing the oils, changing emulsion resistance, increasing stability, hence the separation time. Finally, that type of nanoparticle allows addition into creams, gels and different types of formulation such as powders and sticks (Suh et al., 2019) .

Octyl methoxycinnamate (OMC) encapsulated into liposomes showed not only reduction of skin absorption, increased SPF and effectiveness, but resistance to water exposure. The liposomes are able to release the active into the skin surface, when compared to free agent that was found in other skin layers representing an absorption (Monteiro et al., 2012; Weiss-Angeli et al., 2010) . Ambrogi et al. (2013) used silicate mobil composition of matter pores to entrap OMC. The results were no different than the other encapsulations types. Although the release of the sunscreen agent is lower, when compared to the formulation where the OMC was free. In that case, the use of these type of encapsulation is proposed for photo instable filters and to avoid absorption and adverse reactions.

Aside from vehicle or types of emulsions, encapsulation of sun filter can influence permeation through the skin. Studies performed by Kim et al. (2014b) showed that cyclodextrins and silica may be used as potential ingredients to encapsulate butyl methoxydibenzoylmethane (BMDBM) and benzophenone-3, minimizing these molecules interaction with stratum corneum and decreasing skin permeation. The same was observed by Scalia et al. (2011a) , which used hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β -CD) to encapsulate BMDBM, and further to produce lipid microparticles. Both encapsulations showed great retainment of BDMBM in the stratum corneum,
with an 82% of recovery. Others studies confirmed these results for encapsulated OMC (Monteiro et al., 2012) .

In Monteiro et al. (2012) , liposomes increased the SPF and the water resistance when compared to cyclodextrins. Moreover, cyclodextrins may create less retention in the skin surface when compared to liposomes. Although, these results are not in accordance with Scalia et al.
(2011a), since in its study the cyclodextrins showed more efficiency.

Lipid nanoparticles, a colloidal carrier system, have been commonly investigated as encapsulation material in cosmetic formulation, specially sunscreens (Andréo-Filho et al., 2018; Gilbert et al., 2016; Monteiro et al., 2012; Puglia et al., 2014; Scalia et al., 2011a) . In many studies using different lipid nanoparticles, combined with organic sun filter such as OMC, BP-3 and others, it has showed reduction of sunscreen permeation in the deepest layers of the skin.
Furthermore, the use of polymers to cover the lipid nanoparticles may reduce even more the permeation in the skin (Gilbert et al., 2016) .

Lipid nanocapsules reduces organic filter permeation better than nanoemulsions. That is because nanoemulsion may interact with sunscreen agent and skin, and in a few cases may increase the sunscreen permeation considering the high molecular weight, such as avobenzone (Puglia et al., 2014) .

OMC in combination with botanical urucum oil, an antioxidant-rich vegetable oil, encapsulated in solid lipid nanoparticles were subjected to cutaneous permeation test using skin diffusion method in study performed by Andréo-Filho et al. (2018) . Results showed no significant skin penetration, and sun filter were safe and effective.

Moreover, in the study carried by Martins et al. (2014) , the use of carnauba and bee waxes as lipid nanoparticles, are a good choice to increase formulation stability, reducing organic filter permeation, such as BP-3.

It is also a possibility the use of mesoporous silica (SBA-15), an encapsulation method that also increases formulation viscosity. The SBA-15 creates a discussion about reducing the skin hydration, creating a dried environment that do not allow the permeability potential of the skin (Gilbert et al., 2016) . Moreover, these mesh interact with inorganic filter creating a synergic effect, increasing FPS (Vieira et al., 2019) .

Recently the impacts of UV filters accumulation in the environment and potential risks related to this fact (Ramos et al., 2016) , more specifically, the impacts in coral reefs are being discussed and local legislation are being approved in different locations as Hawaii, Key West in United Stated for example, in order to ban the commercialization of sunscreens containing oxybenzone and octinoxate (Ouchene et al., 2019 ).

The authors Downs et al. (2016) ; He et al. (2019) , demonstrated in different studies the impacts of oxybenzone and octinoxate in coral reefs, correlating directly the presence of UV filters with coral reef bleaching. The UV filters concentration in these studies and the protocol itself s can be controversial, as it is difficult to replicate the real scenario of the oceans and oceans waters flows.

According with Corinaldesi et al. (2018) even inorganic filter, especially ZnO, can impact in marine environment, depositing in the coral reef surface and consequently causing bleaching and damage to corals (Corinaldesi et al., 2018) .

It is also important to mention that several studies suggest that the most deleterious and harmful aspects correlated with the coral deaths are stressors as global sea temperature change and acidification caused by rising atmospheric CO 2 levels. These global warming changes cause coral bleaching and ultimately coral death (Eakin et al., 2010; Precht et al., 2016) .

Aside the Oceans and coral reefs blenching, (Da Silva et al., 2015) found residues of organic filters as Octocrylene and Benzophenone-3, in raw water and drinking water, in cities from São Paulo, Brazil. In addition, UV filters residues were also found in the Iguaçu rivers in Curitiba, SC, Brazil and Guanabara Bay in Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil (Amanda et al., 2017; Mizukawa et al., 2017 ).

It is well-known that the use of sunscreens is essential to protect skin against damages from sun radiation, and its efficacy and safety are key factors in public heathy worldwide. It is also known that sun filters molecules permeation reduces its effectiveness and safety, leading to systemic distribution causing unknown adverse effects. Thus, together with data from clinical trials, the importance of deep evaluation of permeation and toxicological aspects and impacts of UV filters in human organism is reinforced. It is vital to understand not only filters behavior, but also vehicles and raw materials real impact in these products' safety and efficacy. In addition, to formulation components, encapsulation techniques may also interfere in sun filters retention and permeation into skin, being important to evaluate.

We reviewed six techniques to evaluate release and permeation of molecules that have been applied in sunscreen formulations studies in the last decade, i.e. flow-through system, Franz diffusion cell, dialyze bag, tape stripping, traditional in vivo technique and Raman spectroscopy.

According to the literature reviewed, the methods were efficient in detect possible permeation of sun filter through the skin. Other systems have been already described in the literature to evaluate other molecules permeation and thus could be promising strategies to be applied in sunscreen development in the future, as microdialysis (Benfeldt and Serup, 1999; Holmgaard and Nielsen, 2009) and transwell diffusion plates (Boyden, 1962) .

More recently, sunscreen use and its environmental impact have been discussed. As the conscience about sun protection increase among global population, it also increases its effects in population health and in the environment that surround us. Thus, further studies on environmental impacts and how to contour and reduce them are needed.

Investigated the absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of 2-Hydroxy-4methoxybenzophenone (HMB) in rats and mice by gavage administration and dermal application. In rats the dermal absorption of [14C] HMB was high in all vehicles (64-80%, percent of the absorbed dose), except in the lotion (46%). As for paraffin oil, the concentration difference didn't show significantly different of absorption (73% and 80%). Furthermore, in rats, the females shown lower absorption than males, in lotion, and the major excretion of the absorbed dose was in urine and feces. In mice, the males show higher absorption of [14C] HMB in ethanol (~64%), acetone (~57%) and lotion (~37%). The total absorbed dose, was recover in feces and urine. The tissue distribution of [14C] HMB, was similar in the vehicles in the higher concentration, excepting of acetone shown higher absorption. The amount of absorption in lotion and ethanol was the same in females. The recovery of the molecule was better in urine and feces of female mice, in lotion at higher dose. With Mutlu et al. (2020) that in mind, the HMB is absorbed through the skin in rats and mice, which is excreted in urine and feces, in majority. In addition, the mice and rats shown similar absorption in dermal application, and paths of metabolization.

FIGREF7.text: Graphical representation of the study design with tape stripping method. After sunscreen application in vitro in studies using membranes (i.e. from pig ears or donate from human skin reduction surgeries) or in vivo in studies with animals or human volunteers, the membrane will suffer a sequence of stripping using specific tapes. Stripped tapes that contain epidermis layers will be further used to identify the concentration and deep of permeated actives.Figure was created by authors using Servier Medical Art by Servier, The Noun Project and Freepik.

FIGREF8.text: Graphical representation of traditional in vivo method to determine the sunscreen permeation after topical application. The study is characterized to use biological materials such as blood and urine of humans or animals. In addition, organs can also be used in studies with animals.

FIGREF10.text: Graphical representation of Raman spectroscopy method. The Raman spectroscopy is characterized to find vibrational signature of the molecule. The laser emission is transmitted to the skin and collected by the optic fiber, the light diffusion is absorbed and disperse into a holographic grade. The CCD detector capture the light, and creates a Raman spectrum. Figure was created by authors.
